creditline: Lent by the Michael Miller Collection, New York
description: curly, shoulder-length hair; curly beard and moustache; hair rises above forehead; attached to beige, marble base
text:
Zeus, the supreme god of the universe in Greek mythology, was identified with the Roman god, Jupiter. Zeus was traditionally depicted as a powerful, bearded figure. Here, a massive beard and a hairstyle with a tall upsweep, or anastole, encircle the god's broad face, granting him a mature, but not aged appearance.

The corkscrew curls in the hair and beard were created by deeply drilled channels that break up the surface of the mass, a characteristic technique of Roman art during the late 2nd century A.D.
title: Head of Zeus
